pageData.text: In this investigation, you will name organic compounds using the system set by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC). You will explore the rules for applying the IUPAC naming system to <button class='glossary-text'>functional groups</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>aromatic compounds</button>, and multi-group compounds.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText: Activity 1 - 30 minutes

text: Describe the importance of the IUPAC naming system in organic chemistry.
Identify and describe <button class='glossary-text'>functional groups</button> that can be found on organic compounds, including their naming prefixes and suffixes.
Apply the IUPAC naming system to number the carbon atoms in linear and cyclical hydrocarbons and apply these numbers to the name of an organic compound.
Use functional group priorities to correctly name multi-group organic compounds.

pageData.text: Esters are an example of organic compounds. They are commonly used in products where a pleasant smell is the goal, such as perfumes and colognes, and are often described as fruity. The fragrant nature of esters is due to their high volatility, which is influenced by weak intermolecular forces. This allows ester molecules to break away from their source and, in this case, enter our noses to be received by olfactory receptors that line the nose.

Esters are found naturally in fruits or flowers. For example, ethyl ethanoate contributes to the smell we associate with pineapples, isoamyl acetate we associate with bananas, 3-methylbutyl-3-methylbutanoate we associate with apples, and octyl acetate we associate with oranges. As we identify the sources of these fragrances, scientists can then mimic them in artificial flavorings.

pageData.desc: Three dark glass vials on a table with an arrangement of citrus slices, herb sprigs and spices.
pageData.altText: Three dark glass vials on a table with an arrangement of citrus slices, herb sprigs and spices.

pageData.text: More than 90% of the compounds in the world are considered organic compounds. Carbon atoms that make up these compounds form strong bonds amongst themselves and thus can create long, stable chains. To organize these compounds, scientists created a naming system or nomenclature. Many organic compounds have common names that do not follow the naming rules. But unlike a name that follows the rules, common names do not reveal the compound’s chemical structure. For example, aspirin is the common name for the compound 2-acetoxybenzoic acid and menthol is the common name for the compound 5-methyl-2-(propan-2-yl)cyclohexan-1-ol.

IUPAC stands for the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. It was founded in 1919 by chemists looking to establish international standards for weights, measures, names and symbols in their field. Today, IUPAC is the authority on chemical nomenclature and terminology. The standards for naming organic compounds are known as the IUPAC System of Nomenclature.

are a class of hydrocarbons in which the atoms are connected by single bonds. Naming an organic compound, such as an alkane, starts with a stem name indicating the number of carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain. A chain of one to four carbon atoms uses chemistry-specific stems to indicate the number of carbons. When there are five or more carbons in the chain the stem names use Greek prefixes (Table 1). Alkanes end with the suffix -ane. Figure 1 shows some examples of simple alkanes.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Three simple alkane molecules. The first molecule has a carbon atom attached to four hydrogens and is labeled methane. The second molecule has three carbons attached to eight hydrogens and is labeled propane. The third molecule has six carbons attached to fourteen hydrogens and is labeled hexane.

pageData.text: If the <button class='glossary-text'>alkane</button>, or other organic compound, is branched, the stem name describes the number of carbons in the longest continuous chain. Branches on hydrocarbons are also known as <button class='glossary-text'>substituents</button>. Numbers are assigned to each carbon atom in this parent chain, as shown in Figure 2. The direction of the numbering must give the lowest numbers to the carbon atoms with substituents.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Two branched hydrocarbons with five carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain and a sixth carbon branching from the third carbon in the chain. The first molecule designates each carbon atom with the letter C. The second molecule designates each carbon atom in the longest continuous chain with the numbers 1 through 5, with the sixth carbon branching from the number 3 in the chain designated as a letter C.

pageData.text: A carbon branch comprised of only single bonds is named as an , which is also an alkane that is missing one hydrogen atom (Figure 3). Alkyl groups are always attached to carbon chains as they cannot exist on their own. This group is named by using the suffix –yl while also using the stem name describing the number of carbons in the group. Identify substituents by their location and length first, then add the name of the parent chain. For example, the branched hydrocarbon in Figure 2 would be named 3-methylpentane.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: An alkyl group made up of one carbon atoms attached to three hydrogen atoms.

pageData.text: For hydrocarbons with more than one branch, number the branches as you would normally and list them before the parent chain name in alphabetical order. Use hyphens to separate numbers from names and commas to separate numbers from each other. If you have more than one of the same type, use the prefixes di-, tri-, tetra-, and so on to indicate how many times it occurs. These prefixes do not affect the alphabetical ordering of substituents. For example, the molecule in Figure 4 would be named 2,3-dimethylhexane.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: A branched hydrocarbon with six carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a one carbon <button class='glossary-text'>alkyl group</button> attached to the second carbon atom in the parent chain and another one carbon alkyl group attached to the third carbon in the parent chain.

pageData.text: To name a branched substituent, use the naming rules as you would normally and surround the substituent name with parentheses. To finish the compound’s name, continue identifying the location of the substituent and name the parent chain. For example, the molecule in Figure 5 would be named 3-(1-mehtylethyl)hexane.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: A branched hydrocarbon with six carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain. Branching from the third carbon in the parent chain is a two-carbon alkyl group with a one carbon alkyl group branching from the first carbon atom in the two-carbon branch.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Naming an organic compound, such as an alkane, starts with a stem name indicating the number of carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain. Table 1 shows stem names from 1-10.Alkanes end with the suffix -ane. If the alkane, or other organic compound, is branched, the stem name describes the number of carbons in the longest continuous chain. Numbers are assigned to each carbon atom in this parent chain, as shown in Figure 2. The direction of the numbering must give the lowest numbers to the carbon atoms with substituents. A carbon branch comprised of only single bonds is named as an alkyl group, which is also an alkane that is missing one hydrogen atom. Alkyl groups are always attached to carbon chains as they cannot exist on their own. This group is named by using the suffix –yl while also using the stem name describing the number of carbons in the group. Identify substituents by their location and length first, then add the name of the parent chain.

pageData.text: in the form of rings are called . To name a cycloalkane with no , start with the prefix cyclo-, then number of carbon atoms in the ring with the stem name, and end with the suffix –ane. For example, the molecule in Figure 6 would be named methylcyclopentane. If there is one substituent, the carbon atoms in the ring do not need to be numbered. If there are substituents in multiple locations, number the carbons in the ring so that each substituent has the lowest possible number. When there are only two substituents, the one that would come first alphabetically is attached to carbon 1. For example, the molecule in Figure 6 would be named 1-ethyl-3-methylcyclopentane.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: A cyclical hydrocarbon made of five carbon atoms with a two-carbon alkyl group attached to the first carbon atom in the ring, and a one carbon alkyl group attached to the third carbon in the ring.

pageData.subTitle: Alkenes and Beyond
pageData.text: An is a hydrocarbon that contains one or more carbon-carbon double bonds. The simplest alkene is ethene, also known as ethylene. An is a hydrocarbon that contains a carbon-carbon triple bond. The simplest alkyne is ethyne, also known as acetylene. Naming alkenes and alkynes is very similar to naming . Start by naming the longest continuous chain that contains the carbon-carbon double or triple bond (Figure 7). Alkenes use the suffix –ene; alkynes use the suffix -yne. Number this parent chain from the end nearest the double or triple bond and indicate the position of the bond with the lowest possible number.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Two hydrocarbon with four carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain. The first molecule has a double bond between the first and second carbon atoms, and its carbon atoms are labeled from right to left with the numbers one through four. The second molecule has a triple bond between the second and third carbon atoms, and its carbon atoms are labeled from left to right with the numbers one through four.

pageData.text: If there are any <button class='glossary-text'>substituents</button>, give the location and name of each in alphabetical order prior to the name of the parent chain. Naming substituents for alkenes and alkynes follows the same rules as for alkanes. For example, the molecule in Figure 8 would be named 2,3-dimethyl-2-butyne.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: A hydrocarbon with four carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a triple bond between the second and third carbon atoms. The carbon atoms are labeled from left to right with the numbers one through four. Attached to each of the second and third carbon atoms in the chain are one carbon alkyl groups.

pageData.text: Some <button class='glossary-text'>alkenes</button> are cyclical and are called <button class='glossary-text'>cycloalkenes</button>. When naming a cycloalkene with <button class='glossary-text'>substituents</button>, it is assumed that the double bond is between the first and second carbons. To number the rest of the carbon atoms, proceed in the direction around the ring that will give the substituent(s) the lowest number. For example, the molecule in Figure 9 would be named 3,4-dimethylcyclopentene.

pageData.altText: Figure 9: A cyclical hydrocarbon with five carbon atoms forming the ring with a double bond between the first and second carbon atoms, and one carbon alkyl groups attached to each of the third and fourth carbons in the ring.

pageData.text: The double bond in is rigid, therefore the groups attached to the double bond do not rotate. This means alkenes may have two different structures, or , indicated by the prefixes cis- or trans-. The molecule in Figure 10a is a cis isomer because two large groups, such as or halogen atoms, are on the same side of the double bond. This isomer is a different compound from its trans counterpart (Figure 10b), with different physical and chemical properties. The molecule in Figure 10b is a trans isomer because the large groups are on opposite sides of the double bond. A trans isomer is generally more stable than its cis counterpart because the large groups are farther apart.

pageData.altText:
Figure 10: Two ball and stick models of two carbon atoms double bonded together with a halogen atom and a hydrogen atom attached to each carbon.
 A) The halogen atoms are found on the top half of the molecule and the hydrogen atoms are found on the bottom half of the molecule.
 B) The left carbon atom has a hydrogen atom on top and a halogen atom on bottom. The right carbon has a halogen atom on top and a hydrogen atom on bottom.
pageData.desc: Figure 10: Two ball and stick models of two carbon atoms double bonded together with a halogen atom and a hydrogen atom attached to each carbon. A) The halogen atoms are found on the top half of the molecule and the hydrogen atoms are found on the bottom half of the molecule. B) The left carbon atom has a hydrogen atom on top and a halogen atom on bottom. The right carbon has a halogen atom on top and a hydrogen atom on bottom.

pageData.text: It may help you to visualize cis-trans isomerism by modeling the differences in rotation between a single bond and a double bond. Start by putting the fingertips of your index fingers together, the thumbs on each hand pointing up. Your index fingers represent a carbon-carbon single bond while your thumbs and other fingers represent the rest of the compound. Keeping your index fingers together, twist your hands and change the position of the thumbs relative to each other. How has the relationship of your other fingers changed?

Now place the tips of your index and middle fingers together to model a carbon-carbon double bond. Repeat the twisting of one hand to reposition your thumbs relative to one another. Can you change the location of your thumbs without breaking the double bond? The lack of flexibility you have when moving your hands with two fingers touching represents the lack of rotation about a double bond. When both thumbs are pointing up, you have a cis <button class='glossary-text'>isomer</button>; when one thumb is pointing down and one thumb is pointing up you have a trans isomer.

pageData.question: Which of the following is the correct IUPAC name for this compound?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There is no cis-trans isomerism if there are two identical groups attached to one of the double-bonded carbons.

imageData.desc: A hydrocarbon with five carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain, with a double bond between the second and third carbon atoms in the chain. The second and fourth carbon atoms in the chain are each attached to one-carbon alkyl groups.
imageData.altText: A hydrocarbon with five carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain, with a double bond between the second and third carbon atoms in the chain. The second and fourth carbon atoms in the chain are each attached to one-carbon alkyl groups.

pageData.question: Which of the following is a cis isomer?

optionImg.altText: A hydrocarbon with two carbons double bonded to each other. Attached to the first carbon in the double bond is a two-carbon alkyl group and a hydrogen atom. Attached to the second carbon in the double bond is a one-carbon alkyl group and a hydrogen atom. The attached alkyl groups are on the same side of the double bond.

A hydrocarbon with two carbons double bonded to each other. Attached to the first carbon in the double bond are two different two-carbon alkyl groups. Attached to the second carbon in the double bond is a one-carbon alkyl group and a hydrogen atom.

A hydrocarbon with two carbons double bonded to each other. Attached to the first carbon in the double bond is a two-carbon alkyl group and a hydrogen atom. Attached to the second carbon in the double bond is a two-carbon alkyl group and a hydrogen atom. The attached alkyl groups are on opposite sides of the double bond.

A hydrocarbon with two carbons double bonded to each other. Attached to the first carbon in the double bond is a two-carbon alkyl group and a hydrogen atom. Attached to the second carbon in the double bond are two different hydrogen atoms.

options.text: None of these are cis isomers.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Cis isomers have substituents on the same side of the double bond.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Naming alkenes and alkynes is very similar to naming alkanes. Start by naming the longest continuous chain that contains the carbon-carbon double bond, followed by the suffix –ene. Number this parent chain from the end nearest the double or triple bond and indicate the position of the bond with the lowest possible number. If there are any substituents, give the location and name of each in alphabetical order prior to the name of the parent chain. Naming substituents for alkenes and alkynes follows the same rules as for alkanes. The double bond in alkenes is rigid, therefore the groups attached to the double bond do not rotate. This means alkenes may have two different isomers indicated by the prefixes cis- or trans-. The molecule in Figure 10a is a cis isomer because two large groups, such as alkyl groups, are on the same side of the double bond. The molecule in Figure 10b is a trans isomer because the large groups are on opposite sides of the double bond.

If there are any substituents, give the location and name of each in alphabetical order prior to the name of the parent chain. Naming substituents for alkenes and alkynes follows the same rules as for alkanes. The double bond in alkenes is rigid, therefore the groups attached to the double bond do not rotate. This means alkenes may have two different isomers indicated by the prefixes cis- or trans-. The molecule in Figure 10a is a cis isomer because two large groups, such as alkyl groups, are on the same side of the double bond. The molecule in Figure 10b is a trans isomer because the large groups are on opposite sides of the double bond.

pageData.text: Back in the early 19th century when benzene (C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>6</sub>) was first isolated, many of the compounds containing benzene had fragrant odors and were thus called <button class='glossary-text'>aromatic compounds</button>. Benzene is a six-carbon ring with each carbon double bonded to an adjacent carbon. The atoms are arranged in a flat ring and thus form an extremely stable structure. Benzene is often represented as a hexagon with a circle in the center. Many aromatic compounds were important to society long before the IUPAC naming rules and have common names that are still in use - and accepted by IUPAC - today. For example, the molecule in Figure 11 would be named hydroxybenzene according to IUPAC nomenclature, however, it is known almost exclusively by the common name phenol.

pageData.altText: Figure 11: A benzene ring with a hydroxyl group attached to a carbon atom in the ring.

pageData.text: When a compound contains a benzene ring with a single <button class='glossary-text'>substituent</button> and the common names cannot be used, it is usually named as a benzene derivative. For example, the molecule in Figure 12 would be named propylbenzene. When a benzene ring has two substituents, the benzene ring is numbered to give the lowest numbers to the substituents (same as when naming <button class='glossary-text'>cycloalkanes</button>). If the common names toluene, aniline or phenol can be used, the carbon atom attached to the methyl, amine or <button class='glossary-text'>hydroxyl group</button> is numbered carbon 1.

pageData.altText: Figure 12: A benzene ring with a three-carbon alkyl group attached to the first carbon atom in the ring.

pageData.text: The position of two is often described using the prefixes ortho- (o), meta- (m), and para- (p). An ortho- arrangement indicates substituents at carbons 1 and 2; a meta- arrangement indicates substituents at carbons 1 and 3; a para- arrangement indicates substituents at carbons 1 and 4. For example, in Figure 13 the molecules can be named, from left to right, o-diethylbenzene, m-diethylbenzene, and p-diethylbenzene.

pageData.altText: Figure 13: Three aromatic molecules. This first molecule is a benzene ring with a two-carbon alkyl group attached to each of the first and second carbon atoms in the ring. The second molecule is a benzene ring with a two-carbon alkyl group attached to each of the first and third carbon atoms in the ring. The third molecule is a benzene ring with a two-carbon alkyl group attached to each of the first and fourth carbon atoms in the ring.

pageData.text: Benzene rings with three or more substituents follow the same rules as for naming substituents on <button class='glossary-text'>cycloalkanes</button>. The substituents are numbered to give the lowest numbers and are named alphabetically.

pageData.subTitle: Substituents
pageData.text: Besides , a common to hydrocarbons is a halogen atom, also called a . Naming halo groups follows the same rules as naming other substituents. Examples of hydrocarbons with halo groups are shown in Figure 14 and are named 2-fluoro-4-methylpentane, 4-ethyl-2-iodohexane, trans-1-bromo-1-propene and 4,5-dichloro-3-ethylcyclohexane, respectively.

pageData.altText: Figure 14: 4 hydrocarbons with halo groups. The first molecule has 5 carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a fluorine atom attached to the second carbon atom and a one-carbon alkyl group attached to the fourth carbon atom. The second molecule has 6 carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a iodine atom attached to the second carbon atom and a two-carbon alkyl group attached to the fourth carbon atom. The third molecule has 3 carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a double bond between the second and third carbon atoms; attached to the second carbon is a hydrogen atom; attached to the third carbon atom is a hydrogen atom and a bromine atom, both on the opposite side of the double bond from the first carbon atom. The fourth molecule is a cyclical hydrocarbon with 6 carbon atoms and a double bond between the first and second carbon atoms; attached to the third carbon is a two-carbon alkyl group; attached to the fourth and fifth carbon atoms are two different chlorine atoms.

pageData.text: Specific groups of atoms that can bond to hydrocarbons are called <button class='glossary-text'>functional groups</button>, and they give compounds similar properties. Identifying a compound’s functional groups allows scientists to predict their chemical reactions. Groups such as carbon-carbon double bonds and benzene rings have already been discussed. Part of the IUPAC naming system involves classifying compounds by their functional groups. We will continue exploring organic compounds by taking a closer look at these classes:

• Alcohol
  • Thiol
  • Ether
  • Aldehyde
  • Ketone
  • Carboxylic acid
  • Ester
  • Amine
  • Amide

The in an alcohol is the (-OH) bonded to a carbon atom. Compounds in the alcohol family are indicated by the –ol suffix which is numbered to show the location of the hydroxyl group on the parent chain. For parent chains longer than two carbon atoms, numbering starts at the end closest to the hydroxyl group; the hydroxyl group marks the first carbon in a cyclical hydrocarbon. Thiol compounds contain sulfur in the form of a thiol group (-SH). Structures in this family are named similarly to alcohols and use the suffix –thiol. These compounds have a characteristically strong, often disagreeable odor and can be found in foods such as oysters, cheddar cheese and onions.

Ethers contain an oxygen atom attached by single bonds to two hydrocarbons. Simple ethers can use their common names, which are formed by adding the word ether to the names of each hydrocarbon attached to the oxygen listed alphabetically. The IUPAC system requires the longer of the two hydrocarbons act as the parent chain. The smaller hydrocarbon and the oxygen are named as a <button class='glossary-text'>substituent</button> called an <button class='glossary-text'>alkoxy group</button>. For example, the molecule in Figure 15 would be named methoxybenzene.

pageData.altText: Figure 15: A hydrocarbon with a benzene ring single bonded to an oxygen atom which is single bonded to a one-carbon alkyl group.

pageData.text: The that defines compounds in the aldehyde family is the in which a carbon atom is double bonded to an oxygen atom. In an aldehyde, the carbon in the carbonyl group is attached to at least one hydrogen atom and either another hydrogen atom or a hydrocarbon. Aldehydes are named with the suffix –al (or -carbaldehyde when attached to a ring), which does not require a number as it always appears at the beginning of the parent chain. The ketone family also features carbonyl groups, only the carbon atoms of these carbonyls are attached to two hydrocarbons. Ketones use the suffix –one and the carbonyl carbon is numbered if its position is carbon 3 or higher. As with aldehydes, the carbonyl group takes precedence over when it comes to naming, so any hydroxyl are identified by the name hydroxy. Carboxylic acids are like aldehydes and ketones in that their functional group, a , is a carbonyl group attached to a hydroxyl group. Carboxylic acids use the suffix –oic acid. When the longest continuous chain is cyclical, the suffix carboxylic acid is used instead. As with aldehydes, the carboxyl group need not be numbered as it always appears at the beginning of the compound.

Esters are like carboxylic acids but the hydrogen in the carboxyl group is replaced with a hydrocarbon. The name of an ester has two parts: the alkyl name and the carboxylate name (in Figure 16 these color-coded blue and orange, respectively). The alkyl name comes first and describes the hydrocarbon attached to the alcohol portion of the ester. The carboxylate name is second and describes the hydrocarbon attached to the carboxylic acid; this name uses the suffix -oate. The molecule in Figure 16 would be named methyl ethanoate.

pageData.altText: Figure 16: A diagram showing a hydrocarbon with a carbon atom in the far-left position followed by an oxygen atom and two other carbon atoms. An oxygen atom is double bonded to the carbon atom in the third position from the left. One box surrounds the atoms in the first two positions and another box surrounds the atoms in the last two positions. The left box is labeled methanol. The right box is labeled ethanoic acid.

pageData.text: Amine compounds have an (-NH2), which is a derivative of ammonia (NH3). This family uses the suffix –amine (or –diamine when two amine groups are present), which is attached to the stem name of the longest continuous carbon chain to which the nitrogen atom is bonded. In compounds where the hydrogen atoms of the amino group are replaced with hydrocarbons, use the prefix N- to name those groups attached to the nitrogen atom; the molecule in Figure 17a would be named N,1-dimethyl-1-propanamine. When an amino group is considered a in an organic compound, the name amino is used and listed alphabetically with other substituents in the molecule; the molecule in Figure 17b would be named 2-aminoethyl propanoate.

pageData.altText:
Figure 17: Two amine compounds.
 A) A hydrocarbon with 3 carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with an amine group attached to the first carbon atom, and a one-carbon alkyl group attached to the nitrogen atom. Another one-carbon alkyl group is also attached to the first carbon atom.
 B) An ester with a two-carbon chain attached to the oxygen atom from the left and a three-carbon alkyl group attached to the same oxygen atom from the right with another oxygen atom double bonded to the carbon atom of the three-carbon alkyl directly attached to the first oxygen atom. An amine group is attached to the outermost carbon atom in the two-carbon alkyl group.

pageData.text: Amides are a derivative of carboxylic acids in which the is replaced with an amino group. Naming amides is also similar to naming carboxylic acids. When adding the suffix to the name of the compound, drop the –oic acid and replace it with –amide. Use the prefix N- when identifying substituents attached to the nitrogen atom in the amino group.

Organic compounds can be quite complex and often contain more than one <button class='glossary-text'>functional groups</button>. So how do you know which group gives its suffix to the name of the molecule? The IUPAC system ranks each functional group so that the group with the highest priority provides the suffix. Groups with lower rankings are considered <button class='glossary-text'>substituents</button> and their associated prefixes are listed at the beginning of the name. Table 2 lists the priorities of functional groups covered in this investigation in order from highest to lowest.

The functional groups at the very bottom of the priority list are carbon-carbon multiple bonds found in alkenes and . The prefix for an is en- and the prefix for an alkyne is yn-yn- and each prefix requires a number identifying its position in the parent chain. If a double bond and a triple bond are found in the same compound, the names are listed alphabetically which means that the full compound name will end with the suffix –yne unless there are higher priority groups present. If there is a tie when assigning the lowest carbon number, the alkene takes priority.

Some functional groups will always be considered substituents and therefore will only contribute prefixes to the name of a compound. These groups are , ethers and nitrogen groups such as NO2 (nitro-) and N3 (azido-).

pageData.question: Which of the following functional groups is found on a carboxylic acid?

optionImg.altText: A functional group with an oxygen atom single-bonded to a hydrogen atom.
A functional group with a carbon atom double-bonded to an oxygen atom, as well as single bonded to a nitrogen atom, which is single bonded to two different hydrogen atoms.
A functional group with a carbon atom double-bonded to an oxygen atom, as well as single bonded to a second oxygen atom, which is single bonded to a hydrogen atom.
A functional group with an oxygen atom single-bonded to two different hydrocarbon chains.
A functional group with a carbon atom double bonded to an oxygen atom.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Learning the functional groups takes practice. Flashcards can help you review the structure of each group.

pageData.question: Which of the following is the correct classification of this compound?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Although a thiol group is present, the ester group takes priority in this compound.

imageData.desc: A hydrocarbon with four carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a one carbon alkyl group and a thiol group attached to the second carbon atom in the chain. An ester oxygen is attached to the fourth carbon atom in the chain and a one carbon alkyl group is attached to the far side of the ester oxygen atom.
imageData.altText: A hydrocarbon with four carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a one carbon alkyl group and a thiol group attached to the second carbon atom in the chain. An ester oxygen is attached to the fourth carbon atom in the chain and a one carbon alkyl group is attached to the far side of the ester oxygen atom.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The functional group in an alcohol is the hydroxyl group (-OH) bonded to a carbon atom. Thiol compounds contain sulfur in the form of a thiol group (-SH). Ethers contain an oxygen atom attached by single bonds to two hydrocarbons, called an alkoxy group. The functional group that defines compounds in the aldehyde family is the carbonyl group in which a carbon atom is double bonded to an oxygen atom. The ketone family also features carbonyl groups, only the carbon atoms of these carbonyls are attached to two hydrocarbons. Carboxylic acids are like aldehydes and ketones in that their functional group, a carboxyl group, is a carbonyl group attached to a hydroxyl group. Esters are like carboxylic acids but the hydrogen in the carboxyl group is replaced with a hydrocarbon. Amine compounds have an amino group (-NH2). Amides are a derivative of carboxylic acids in which the hydroxyl group is replaced with an amino group. Organic compounds can be quite complex and often contain more than one functional group. The IUPAC system ranks each functional group so that the group with the highest priority provides the suffix. Groups with lower rankings are considered substituents and their associated prefixes are listed at the beginning of the name. Table 2 in the Resources menu lists the priorities of functional groups covered in this investigation in order from highest to lowest.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The functional group in an alcohol is the hydroxyl group (-OH) bonded to a carbon atom. Thiol compounds contain sulfur in the form of a thiol group (-SH). Ethers contain an oxygen atom attached by single bonds to two hydrocarbons, called an alkoxy group. The functional group that defines compounds in the aldehyde family is the carbonyl group in which a carbon atom is double bonded to an oxygen atom. The ketone family also features carbonyl groups, only the carbon atoms of these carbonyls are attached to two hydrocarbons. Carboxylic acids are like aldehydes and ketones in that their functional group, a carboxyl group, is a carbonyl group attached to a hydroxyl group. Esters are like carboxylic acids but the hydrogen in the carboxyl group is replaced with a hydrocarbon. Amine compounds have an amino group (-NH2). Amides are a derivative of carboxylic acids in which the hydroxyl group is replaced with an amino group. Organic compounds can be quite complex and often contain more than one functional group. The IUPAC system ranks each functional group so that the group with the highest priority provides the suffix. Groups with lower rankings are considered substituents and their associated prefixes are listed at the beginning of the name. Table 2 in the Resources menu lists the priorities of functional groups covered in this investigation in order from highest to lowest.

This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is the correct classification of this compound?

imageData.desc: A hydrocarbon with four carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with the first carbon atom double bonded to an oxygen atom and single bonded to a hydrogen atom. The third carbon atom in the chain is attached to a one-carbon alkyl group.
imageData.altText: A hydrocarbon with four carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with the first carbon atom double bonded to an oxygen atom and single bonded to a hydrogen atom. The third carbon atom in the chain is attached to a one-carbon alkyl group.

assestmentData.question: If all the following functional groups were present in the same organic compound, which group would have the highest naming priority according to the IUPAC system?
Use your knowledge of IUPAC nomenclature to determine the correct classification for the molecule cyclohexanone.
Which of the following prefixes describes the position of two substituents at carbons 1 and 2 of an aromatic compound?
Which of the following statements is true about cis-trans isomers?

options.text: Trans isomers are usually more stable.
Cis isomers form around carbon-carbon single bonds.
Trans isomers have substituents on the same side of a carbon-carbon double bond.
Cis isomers have the same properties as their trans counterparts.
Cis isomers have different chemical formulas than their trans counterparts.

pageData.altText: completion

text: Each of the organic compounds in this investigation have a common name and an IUPAC preferred name. When is each type of name appropriate to use?

pageData.altText: Periodic Table of the Elements

pageData.content: Table 1. Stems for naming the longest carbon chain
pageData.title: Table 1.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Three simple alkane molecules. The first molecule has a carbon atom attached to four hydrogens and is labeled methane. The second molecule has three carbons attached to eight hydrogens and is labeled propane. The third molecule has six carbons attached to fourteen hydrogens and is labeled hexane.

pageData.content: Figure 2. Numbering the longest carbon chain
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Two branched hydrocarbons with five carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain and a sixth carbon branching from the third carbon in the chain. The first molecule designates each carbon atom with the letter C. The second molecule designates each carbon atom in the longest continuous chain with the numbers 1 through 5, with the sixth carbon branching from the number 3 in the chain designated as a letter C.
Figure 3: An alkyl group made up of one carbon atoms attached to three hydrogen atoms.

Figure 4: A branched hydrocarbon with six carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a one carbon alkyl group attached to the second carbon atom in the parent chain and another one carbon alkyl group attached to the third carbon in the parent chain.

pageData.content: Figure 5. Numbering carbons in a branched alkane
pageData.altText: Figure 5: A branched hydrocarbon with six carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain. Branching from the third carbon in the parent chain is a two-carbon alkyl group with a one carbon alkyl group branching from the first carbon atom in the two-carbon branch.

Figure 6: A cyclical hydrocarbon made of five carbon atoms with a two-carbon alkyl group attached to the first carbon atom in the ring, and a one carbon alkyl group attached to the third carbon in the ring.

Figure 7: Two hydrocarbon with four carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain. The first molecule has a double bond between the first and second carbon atoms, and its carbon atoms are labeled from right to left with the numbers one through four. The second molecule has a triple bond between the second and third carbon atoms, and its carbon atoms are labeled from left to right with the numbers one through four.

Figure 8: A hydrocarbon with four carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a triple bond between the second and third carbon atoms. The carbon atoms are labeled from left to right with the numbers one through four. Attached to each of the second and third carbon atoms in the chain are one carbon alkyl groups.

Figure 9: A cyclical hydrocarbon with five carbon atoms forming the ring with a double bond between the first and second carbon atoms, and one carbon alkyl groups attached to each of the third and fourth carbons in the ring.

Figure 10: Two ball and stick models of two carbon atoms double bonded together with a halogen atom and a hydrogen atom attached to each carbon.
 A) The halogen atoms are found on the top half of the molecule and the hydrogen atoms are found on the bottom half of the molecule.
 B) The left carbon atom has a hydrogen atom on top and a halogen atom on bottom. The right carbon has a halogen atom on top and a hydrogen atom on bottom.
Figure 11: A benzene ring with a hydroxyl group attached to a carbon atom in the ring.
Figure 12: A benzene ring with a three-carbon alkyl group attached to the first carbon atom in the ring.

pageData.content: Figure 13. Ortho-, meta- and para- arrangements
pageData.altText: Figure 13: Three aromatic molecules. This first molecule is a benzene ring with a two-carbon alkyl group attached to each of the first and second carbon atoms in the ring. The second molecule is a benzene ring with a two-carbon alkyl group attached to each of the first and third carbon atoms in the ring. The third molecule is a benzene ring with a two-carbon alkyl group attached to each of the first and fourth carbon atoms in the ring.

Figure 14: 4 hydrocarbons with halo groups. The first molecule has 5 carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a fluorine atom attached to the second carbon atom and a one-carbon alkyl group attached to the fourth carbon atom. The second molecule has 6 carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a iodine atom attached to the second carbon atom and a two-carbon alkyl group attached to the fourth carbon atom. The third molecule has 3 carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with a double bond between the second and third carbon atoms; attached to the second carbon is a hydrogen atom; attached to the third carbon atom is a hydrogen atom and a bromine atom, both on the opposite side of the double bond from the first carbon atom. The fourth molecule is a cyclical hydrocarbon with 6 carbon atoms and a double bond between the first and second carbon atoms; attached to the third carbon is a two-carbon alkyl group; attached to the fourth and fifth carbon atoms are two different chlorine atoms.
Figure 15: A hydrocarbon with a benzene ring single bonded to an oxygen atom which is single bonded to a one-carbon alkyl group.

pageData.content: Figure 16. Identifying the parts of an ester
pageData.altText: Figure 16: A diagram showing a hydrocarbon with a carbon atom in the far-left position followed by an oxygen atom and two other carbon atoms. An oxygen atom is double bonded to the carbon atom in the third position from the left. One box surrounds the atoms in the first two positions and another box surrounds the atoms in the last two positions. The left box is labeled methanol. The right box is labeled ethanoic acid.

Figure 17: Two amine compounds.
 A) A hydrocarbon with 3 carbon atoms in the longest continuous chain with an amine group attached to the first carbon atom, and a one-carbon alkyl group attached to the nitrogen atom. Another one-carbon alkyl group is also attached to the first carbon atom. 
 B) An ester with a two-carbon chain attached to the oxygen atom from the left and a three-carbon alkyl group attached to the same oxygen atom from the right with another oxygen atom double bonded to the carbon atom of the three-carbon alkyl directly attached to the first oxygen atom. An amine group is attached to the outermost carbon atom in the two-carbon alkyl group.

pageData.content: Table 2. Functional groups in order of descending priority
pageData.title: Table 2.

data.title: Alkane
data.content: A class of hydrocarbons in which the atoms are connected by single bonds.

data.title: Alkene
data.content: A class of hydrocarbons in which the molecule contains one or more carbon-carbon double bonds.

data.title: Alkoxy group
data.content: an oxygen atom attached by single bonds to the smaller of two hydrocarbons.

data.title: Alkyl group
data.content: A type of substituent consisting of a carbon branch comprised of only single bonds.

data.title: Alkyne
data.content: A class of hydrocarbons in which the molecule contains one or more carbon-carbon triple bonds.

data.title: Aromatic compound
data.content: A class of cyclical hydrocarbons in which the parent ring is benzene.

data.title: Carbonyl group
data.content: A carbon atom double bonded to an oxygen atom.

data.title: Carboxyl group
data.content: A carbonyl group attached to a hydroxyl group.

data.title: Cycloalkane
data.content: An alkane in which the parent chain forms a ring.

data.title: Cycloalkene
data.content: An alkene in which the parent chain forms a ring.

data.title: Functional group
data.content: A class of substituents in which a group of atoms gives the parent molecule specific properties.

data.title: Halo group
data.content: A type of substituent consisting of a halogen atom.

data.title: Isomers
data.content: Molecules with the same molecular structure but different spatial arrangement of the atoms in the molecule.

data.title: Substituent
data.content: An atom, or group of atoms, other than hydrogen connected to the parent chain or ring in a hydrocarbon molecule.
